tool.name: bedtools WindowBed
tool.description: find overlapping intervals within a window around an interval

param.name: bed
param.label: When using BAM input, write output as BED. The default is to write output in BAM when using a bam file

param.name: addition_select
param.label: Choose what you want to do
param.option: Add Base pairs for **both** upstream and downstream of each entry in A when searching for overlaps in B
Add Base pairs **separately** for upstream and downstream of each entry in A when searching for overlaps in B

param.name: w
param.label: Base pairs to add upstream and downstream

param.name: l
param.label: Base pairs added upstream (left) of each entry in A when searching for overlaps in B
param.help: Allows one to create assymetrical “windows”. Default is 1000bp. (-l)

param.name: r
param.label: Base pairs added downstream (right) of each entry in A when searching for overlaps in B
param.help: Allows one to create assymetrical “windows”. Default is 1000bp. (-r)

param.name: strandB
param.label: Calculation based on strandedness?
param.option: Only report hits in B that overlap A on the **same** strand
Only report hits in B that overlap A on the **opposite** strand

param.name: original
param.label: Write original A entry once if any overlaps found in B
param.help: In other words, just report the fact at least one overlap was found in B. (-u)

param.name: number
param.label: For each entry in A, report the number of hits in B
param.help: Reports 0 for A entries that have no overlap with B (-c)

param.name: nooverlaps
param.label: Only report those entries in A that have no overlaps with B

tool.help:
**What it does**
Similar to bedtools intersect, window searches for overlapping features in A and B. However, window adds a specified number (1000, by default) of base pairs upstream and downstream of each feature in A. In effect, this allows features in B that are “near” features in A to be detected.
